DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text designations that identify sex; particulary a type of animal.  Sex is described as the assemblage of physical properties or qualities by which male is distinguished from female.  [Explanatory Comment 1:  Identification is based upon observation/phenotype.]  [Explanatory Comment 2:  Phenotype is the outward appearance of the animal. It is the product of interactions between genes and between the genotype and the environment.]  [Explanatory Comment 3: An animal is a living, sentient organism that has membranous cell walls, requires oxygen and organic foods, and is capable of voluntary movement, as distinguished from a plant or mineral.]

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The assemblage of observed physical properties or qualities in which male is distinguished from female in a living, sentient organism that has membranous cell walls, requires oxygen and organic foods, and is capable of voluntary movement, as distinguished from a plant or mineral._The assemblage of physical properties or qualities by which male is distinguished from female; the physical difference between male and female; the distinguishing peculiarity of male or female. (from On-line Medical Dictionary)

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A living, sentient organism that has membranous cell walls, requires oxygen and organic foods, and is capable of voluntary movement, as distinguished from a plant or mineral.

Concepts.definition: A living organism that has membranous cell walls, requires oxygen and organic foods, and is capable of voluntary movement, as distinguished from a plant or mineral.

Property.preferredDefinition: The outward appearance of the individual. It is the product of interactions between genes and between the genotype and the environment. This includes the killer phenotype, characteristic of YEASTS.:The assemblage of physical properties or qualities by which male is distinguished from female; the physical difference between male and female; the distinguishing peculiarity of male or female. (from On-line Medical Dictionary)

Concepts.definition: The assemblage of traits or outward appearance of an individual. It is the product of interactions between genes and between genes and the environment.
The assemblage of physical properties or qualities by which male is distinguished from female; the physical difference between male and female; the distinguishing peculiarity of male or female.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 10/10/2005 The object for this DEC was changed from CL107207 to C28421 to reflect change in preferred term in EVS.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Text designations that identify sex .  Sex is described as the assemblage of physical properties or qualities by which male is distinguished from female.  [Explanatory Comment 1:  Identification is based upon observation/phenotype.]  [Explanatory Comment 2:  Phenotype is the outward appearance of the individual. It is the product of interactions between genes and between the genotype and the environment.] [Explanatory Comment 3:  An animal is a living, sentient organism that has membranous cell walls, requires oxygen and organic foods, and is capable of voluntary movement, as distinguished from a plant or mineral.]

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An organism having both male and female sexual characteristics and organs.

Concepts.definition: An organism having both male and female sexual characteristics and organs.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An animal who is observed by researcher or clinician to be female, the sex that ordinarily produces ova.

Concepts.definition: An animal who is observed by researcher or clinician to be female, the sex that ordinarily produces ova.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An animal who is observed by researcher or clinician to be male, the sex that ordinarily produces sperm.

Concepts.definition: An animal who is observed by researcher or clinician to be male, the sex that ordinarily produces sperm.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not stated explicitly or in detail.

Concepts.definition: Not stated explicitly or in detail.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A person (one of unisexual specimens) who is born with genitalia and/or secondary sexual characteristics of indeterminate sex, or which combine features of both sexes.

Concepts.definition: A person (one of unisexual specimens) who is born with genitalia and/or secondary sexual characteristics of indeterminate sex, or which combine features of both sexes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An organism that was male at birth based on physical characteristics and has undergone hormonal therapy and/or surgical procedures in order to develop more female physical characteristics.

Concepts.definition: An organism that was male at birth based on physical characteristics and has undergone hormonal therapy and/or surgical procedures in order to develop more female physical characteristics.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An organism that was female at birth based on physical characteristics and has undergone hormonal therapy and/or surgical procedures in order to develop more male physical characteristics.

Concepts.definition: An organism that was female at birth based on physical characteristics and has undergone hormonal therapy and/or surgical procedures in order to develop more male physical characteristics.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueDomain.origin: NCISTD: NCI CRF Harmonization and Standards Initiative

ReferenceDocuments.name: Business Rule 2
ReferenceDocuments.description: Phenotype is the outward appearance of the individual. It is the product of interactions between genes and between the genotype and the environment.

ReferenceDocuments.name: 2-COMMENT
ReferenceDocuments.description: Phenotype is the outward appearance of the individual. It is the product of interactions between genes and between the genotype and the environment.

ReferenceDocuments.name: 3-COMMENT
ReferenceDocuments.description: An animal is a living, sentient organism that has membranous cell walls, requires oxygen and organic foods, and is capable of voluntary movement, as distinguished from a plant or mineral.

DataElement.origin: NCISTD: NCI CRF Harmonization and Standards Initiative
